The major presidential polling aggregation sites forecast Trump to be a leader in the Florida primaries.  On GJOpen, and on some sites, Rubio is treated as a somewhat likely second, because Florida is his state. I am hesitant about giving Rubio too much credit here, because his approval ratings are lower than most candidates in their home state. In a recent Florida poll, 44% of Floridians said that they think Rubio should drop out of the race. It seems unlikely that everyone else (56%)  is a strong Rubio supporter and would vote for Rubio over Trump, which is pretty close to what Rubio would need to beat Trump.  Also, although I am open to being wrong here and it is very possible that Trump's campaign doesn't align with campaign norms, it is worth noting that polling sites show that approval ratings for candidates after they win initial primaries tend to improve. Because I haven't found great reason to think otherwise, it is likely that Trump's early wins are helping his chances.   http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/fl/florida_republican_presidential_primary-3555.html
http://www.cbsnews.com/news/election-2016-trump-and-kasich-neck-and-neck-ohio-trump-leads-florida/

Trump has been steadily in the lead ahead of Florida's Rubio for about a week.  This morning's (Monday 14th March) polls from all of the American alphabet networks and Fox News puts him easily 20 points ahead.  My certainty is also backed up by the notion that despite instability at his recent rallies these numbers have held.  If the electorate's faith in Trump as a secure candidate had been rocked this would have been reflected in the most recent polls.  The print media is also pretty sure of a Trump win, the Wall Street Journal even headlining an article: 'Rubio backers look for miracle ahead of Florida Primary.' However, there is the doubt afforded by voter fraud. Florida is wrapping up a wapping TEN DAYS of early voting.  Trump as well as other political pundits, went to social media to express concerns of voter fraud in the state, with the possibility of Republicans trying to rig the vote in favour of Rubio.  Wadi Gatan, a spokesman for the Florida Republican Party, said the party also was unaware of early-voting irregularities.  If Trump DOES lose, given the consistent figures of such a wide margin in the polls, fraud would be the only reason.

Because Kierke Gaard is just an experiment in pure hedgehog tactics, that is, all forecasts must be either 0% or 100%, I don't normally make any comments. However, because several people now are following me, I feel duty bound to warn them that I may have made a huge mistake on this question. I'm flipping from Trump at 100% to 0% on the basis of this analysis: https://s3.amazonaws.com/ei-static/Pathto1237Memo-031116.pdf.  Thank you, @austerity for pointing this out. To summarize: 1. As of today, March 13, with 463 delegates out of the 1,049 delegates that have been won by all candidates combined, Trump is holding the narrowest lead of any Republican nomination contest in *forty years.*  2. Trump’s base is not growing even as the field winnows.  3. Florida is a closed primary state, meaning only registered Republican may vote. Trump has lost two of the three closed primaries so far, and won by only a 3% plurality edge in Louisiana. I'm now placing my 100% bet on Rubio as Florida's favorite son. But please remember, I am only a scoring experiment! @BG1, @lsgold7, @dada, @dowser, @ALM21, @madre, @malcmur, @JP, @Khalid, @ravel, @GeneH, @Heffalump, @GL2184, @patrickmeehan5, @jeremylichtman, @GJDrew

The current polls strongly favor Trump[a], though I think they might understate Rubio's chances of winning slightly. Why? Because of the latter's connection with many communities in Florida (e.g., Cuban-Americans are said to favor Rubio over Trump 57-to-13[b]). And because Floridians voted Rubio into the Senate for Pete's sake! And because Rubio might have ground-game resources that pollsters aren't well positioned to estimate[c]. But I just can't see how Cruz and Kasich are to be taken seriously at this point. There are some reports that Cruz has given upon Florida[d]. Sure, the probability of either winning isn't really zero, but it's so close that we might as well treat it that way. Hey, it's 2016. Nothing unexpected happens in American politics anymore, right? -- [a] http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/primary-forecast/florida-republican/

This final debate was the final opportunity for Rubio to dramatically reverse the direction of the Florida primary. Though he had a good night with great answers on Social Security (hugely important in Florida) and Cuba, there were no particularly powerful moments. Cruz also had an alright night, meaning he will likely hold onto his share of votes, as did Kasich.  In contrast, for the first time in the recent debates Trump was calm, focusing on electability and appearing 'presidential.' With multiple speaking opportunities for rebuttals and constant calls for unification as a party, his frontrunner status is secured.  Finally, the RNC chair's comments about supporting the nominee no matter what legitimizes Trump's campaign further, especially among establishment voters.

My suspicion is that Trump appeals to the disenfranchised and those without the skills necessary to work at anything much beyond the service industry and/or manual labor, though, of course, there are exceptions, as there always are. Trump is almost a litmus test for those who rarely take the time to consider the complexity that problems can have, and want to believe that their simplistic solutions are viable, hence they flock to any politician espousing those same simplistic answers. Florida is the destination-of-choice for unskilled and semi-skilled workers from the northeast, modestly employed in Florida, and want to believe that someone can bring back high-paying jobs for semi-skilled workers who don't understand that Trump's solution of "getting better deals with China" is code for "starting a trade-war with the rest of the world." The most memorable trade-war was, in my opinion, triggered by  the Smoot-Hawley act of circa-1930-32 which impacted Europe and Germany, prolonged the Great Depression, pushed Germany into hyper-inflation, and ultimately led to the rise of Adolf Hitler. The rule of unintended consequences may not predict another Hitler, but the possibility/probability that a major trade-war led by the US would not end well. Trump may not be that dumb, but he is certainly trying to appeal to the most basic emotional triggers of those disenfranchised among us, quite successfully, I might add.

Start with the 538 polls-only forecast. (Polls-plus forecasts underrate Trump, who has no endorsements.) So Trump 88, Rubio 11, Cruz ~1. What's the model missing? The Pro-Trump Case
(1) About 600,000 early ballots are in already. They probably favour Trump heavily. How much do they matter? In 2012 there were only 1.6 million votes in total. Turnout in general is up 25%, so the early ballots probably reflect 30% of the final total. Assume they follow the current polling, in which Trump has a 15% lead over Rubio and a 30% lead over Cruz: then Trump has locked in a 4.5% advantage over Rubio and a 9% advantage over Cruz, meaning Rubio needs to beat Trump by 6.5% to catch up, and Cruz by 13%. That seems hard! (2) Rubio, Trump's main Florida rival, seems to be tanking. If anything, the party is considering lining up behind Cruz, which could split Rubio's vote without giving Cruz time to catch up. The Anti-Trump Case
(1) Romney's appeal for every anti-Trump voter to vote Rubio, or some similar establishment plea, might be successful.
(2) The Puerto Rico win might perhaps turn things around for Rubio?
(3) Trump seems to underperform in closed primaries.
(4) A wave of anti-Trump advertising might take. Overall, the model looks likely to understate Trump's odds, but not by very much. I'll also increase Cruz to reflect his recent momentum.
The anti-Trump movement has already gathered significant momentum.

Raising Trump 6 (lowering Rubio 6). While Rubio had a "poor" day today, you could argue that Trump had a "worse" day, with the way that Cruz (!) surged. With that being said, today's showing makes it look TERRIBLE for Rubio's chances in Florida on the 15th. There's still lots to happen between now and then, but I wanted to get one "day" in where I was significantly (?) above the consensus on Trump (currently at 78). Here's what's happening in the next 10 days: Mar 6: Puerto Rico 
Mar 8: Hawaii, Idaho, Michigan, Mississippi ***MAR 10***: GOP Debate (in Miami!) Mar 12: DC, Guam 
Mar 15: Florida (among others) I expect that Rubio will do well tomorrow in Puerto Rico and tomorrow night, I expect that I'll temper Trump back into the 80s. It will be very important to see what kind of polls are released on Monday (Mar 7), if any, and then to track the contests on Tuesday. I don't expect that Rubio will do *well* in any of them, but it'll be important to see how Trump does and whether voters really see Cruz as the alternative to Trump. If that's the case, then it might be that Florida is assured for Trump (as I don't see a scenario where Cruz wins enough in Florida to overtake Rubio AND Trump). With that being said, as you can see from my calendar, there's still lots between now and then, so maybe it is possible that Cruz overtakes both of them.
